corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of manuscripts, sound recordings, graphic images, and moving images created and collected by John Cohen. The materials document Cohen's parallel careers as a musician (member of the New Lost City Ramblers) and writer during the 1960s American folk music revival, and his celebrated work as a documentary photographer and filmmaker, producer, and artist from the 1950s to the present. Includes interviews made by Cohen with John Hartford, Harry Smith, Roger McGuinn, Pete Seeger, Bob Dylan, Gary Davis, John Summers, Cousin Emmy, Roscoe Holcomb, Charlie Higgins, Wade Ward, Friends of Old Time Music, High Atmosphere, and photographs of these and others including E. C. Ball, Clancy Brothers, Elizabeth Cotten, Willie Dixon, Jack Elliott, Woody Guthrie, Mary Frank, Lilly Brothers, Alan Lomax, Bill Monroe, Earl Scruggs, Mike Seeger, Stanley Brothers, Belle Stewart, Stony Mountain Boys, Merle Travis, Muddy Waters, Doc Watson and many others. The collection includes documentation of Greenwich Village and Harlem, New York City; Cohen's travels to Paris and Spain in the 1950s; and later to England, Wales, Scotland, Germany, Italy and Japan, and other countries. Notable is his research for his master's thesis on Peruvian textile weaving, and subsequent fieldwork in Peru. Subsequent projects in Peru incorporated sound recordings of Andean music, and films as well as books about weaving, music, festivals, and dance. The majority of Cohen's Peru photographs were taken during his first three trips there and focus primarily on indigenous Andean people in the Q'ero region.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Materials in this collection were in the possession of John Cohen and his family until their donation to the American Folklife Center.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Original acquisition received in 2011; Additional accruals received in January 2020 and August 2021; Additional accrual expected in 2022/2023.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The John Cohen collection was processed by Marcia Segal, Marlan Green, David Quick, Kate Stewart, Valda Morris, and Maya Lerman in 2012; 2018-2022.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: John Cohen was born in 1932 in Queens, New York, to Russian Jewish parents, Israel Cohen and Sonya (Shack) Cohen, and raised on Long Island. Cohen earned a bachelor of fine arts (1951) and completed a master of fine arts (1957), both from Yale University. As an undergraduate, Cohen studied painting with artist and educator, Josef Albers, but shifted his focus to photography after being exposed to Robert Frank's documentary photography work. He studied with modernist photographer Herbert Matter, who Cohen assisted on a project documenting performances of gospel music in Harlem. Cohen's deepening artistic sense, combined with learning about weaving customs of Peru through an archeology course, would lead him to travel to the Peruvian Andes, write his master's thesis on their weaving customs, and commence his lifelong involvement documenting Andean communities.

Cohen was also an active musician. While at Yale, he organized music festivals and continued his work presenting concerts later in New York City during the emergence of the folk revival. In 1958, Cohen founded the New Lost City Ramblers, along with Mike Seeger and Tom Paley (replaced by Tracy Schwarz in 1962). The New Lost City Ramblers was an old time string band that embraced a respect for rural Appalachian traditions and canons, while infusing originality and making the music accessible to folk revival audiences in New York City and throughout the United States. The band created more than 20 albums together.

While living in New York City during the late 1950s, Cohen became involved with the Avant Garde and Abstract Expressionist art world. Robert Frank, Cohen's next door neighbor, enlisted Cohen as still photographer of
Pull My Daisy
, the influential Beat Generation film directed by Frank, written by Jack Kerouac, and featuring Allen Ginsberg, Peter Orlovsky, Gregory Corso, David Amram, and others. In addition to documenting the artistic Avant Garde art and literary world of his New York neighborhood, Cohen photographed significant folk musicians, such as Woody Guthrie and a young Bob Dylan. He was a founding director of the Friends of Old Time Music, a group including Ralph Rinzler and Izzy Young, which presented 14 concerts of traditional musicians to New York audiences for the first time. Performers included Roscoe Holcomb, the Stanley Brothers, Maybelle Carter, Doc Watson, Mississippi John Hurt, and Dock Boggs. In addition to using his musical and personal connections for booking artists, John did the artwork and design for posters and fliers for many of the concerts.

In 1965, Cohen married Penelope (Penny) Seeger (1943-1993), daughter of the well-known musicians and musicologists Ruth Crawford Seeger and Charles Seeger. Penny was a singer and musician, as were her siblings, Barbara, Peggy, Mike (John Cohen's band mate in the New Lost City Ramblers), and half brother, Pete. Cohen and Seeger had two children, Sonya (1965-2015) and Rufus.

Cohen's fascination with Appalachian and Andean culture inspired him to take many collecting trips to the Southern U.S. and to Peru, where he recorded, photographed, and produced films that presented the people and traditions in their cultural contexts. His work reflected his artistic sense and aesthetic. Cohen was a prolific documentary filmmaker, ultimately creating seventeen films through the course of his career, including
The High Lonesome Sound
,
The End of an Old Song
,
Q'eros: The Shape of Survival
,
Mountain Music of Peru
, and
Visions of Mary Frank
. Cohen also produced, compiled, and wrote liner notes for recordings of Appalachian music, such as
An Untamed Sense of Control
,
High Atmosphere: Ballads and Banjo Tunes from Virginia and North Carolina
,
Dark Holler
, and
Back Roads to Cold Mountain
.

Cohen guest lectured at several colleges beginning in 1968, before becoming the Area Head in photography at the State University of New York at Purchase from 1972 to 1997. There he taught courses on photography, drawing, and film. His photographs have been exhibited at galleries and museums across the United States and in Peru and England. The
There Is No Eye
exhibit of Cohen's photographs, organized by the Photographic Resource Center in Boston, MA, traveled to 11 museums and yielded a book of photographs and a Smithsonian Folkways album,
There Is No Eye: Music for Photographs
. Cohen's photographs have been published in numerous curated books, and in periodicals. Cohen died in 2019.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection of manuscripts, sound recordings, graphic images, and moving images created and collected by John Cohen. The materials document Cohen's parallel careers as a musician (member of the New Lost City Ramblers) and writer during the 1960s American folk music revival, and his celebrated work as a documentary photographer and filmmaker, producer, and artist from the 1950s to the present. Includes interviews made by Cohen with John Hartford, Harry Smith, Roger McGuinn, Pete Seeger, Bob Dylan, Gary Davis, John Summers, Cousin Emmy, Roscoe Holcomb, Charlie Higgins, Wade Ward, Friends of Old Time Music, High Atmosphere, and photographs of these and others including E. C. Ball, Clancy Brothers, Elizabeth Cotten, Willie Dixon, Jack Elliott, Woody Guthrie, Mary Frank, Lilly Brothers, Alan Lomax, Bill Monroe, Earl Scruggs, Mike Seeger, Stanley Brothers, Belle Stewart, Stony Mountain Boys, Merle Travis, Muddy Waters, Doc Watson and many others. The collection includes documentation of Greenwich Village and Harlem, New York City; Cohen's travels to Paris and Spain in the 1950s; and later to England, Wales, Scotland, Germany, Italy and Japan, and other countries. Notable is his research for his master's thesis on Peruvian textile weaving, and subsequent fieldwork in Peru. Cohen visited Peru eight times between 1956 and 2005. Subsequent projects in Peru incorporated sound recordings of Andean music, and films as well as books about weaving, music, festivals, and dance. The majority of Cohen's Peru photographs were taken during his first three trips there and focus primarily on indigenous Andean people in the Q'ero region.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The John Cohen collection is organized into the following series:

item.ref: Series 2. Sound recordings and moving images

arrangement.p: Series 1-3 were arranged and described according to format, such as manuscripts and sound recordings. Series 4 was processed separately, and is mostly arranged topically, by Cohen's area of interest, such as Peru and Southern U.S. music, but there is also a large subseries that documents the administrative side of Cohen's teaching, writing, photography, and film making career. Sound recordings that do not fit into the topical subseries of Series 4 have been moved to "Series 2. Subseries 4. Sound recordings and moving image materials from 2020 accrual." Materials within the Series 4 subseries are arranged alphabetically except for the "Original Artwork" subseries, which is arranged chronologically.
Headings in titles, such as "New Lost City Ramblers" and "Hidden Threads of Peru," were provided to uphold the collection's original order according to the topics of Cohen's projects and endeavors.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: Manuscript materials related to John Cohen's film projects, musical career, photography, and writing. Includes materials related to the production of Cohen's films, correspondence, ephemera related to the New Lost City Ramblers, writings for liner notes and articles, and interview transcripts.

Manuscript materials related to Cohen's film projects. Includes royalty statements, transcriptions, and translations. Materials provide evidence of business transactions and artistic decisions made throughout the production and distribution of Cohen's films.

scopecontent.p:
Materials relating to Cohen's relationship with and films about Roscoe Holcomb, including correspondence, transcriptions, ephemera, posters, contracts and prints. Correspondence and materials regarding the album,
Mountain Music of Kentucky
, and the film,
Roscoe Holcomb: From Daisy, Kentucky
. Includes materials relating to the New Lost City Ramblers, including posters and fliers, photographs, correspondence, contracts, notes, drafts of liner notes, festival programs, newspaper clippings, and magazine articles. Materials reflect the New Lost City Ramblers' touring and recorded work. Also included are the Putnam String County Band posters and materials relating to the Friends of Old Time Music. Other items in the subseries include the New Tranquility String Band recording project, the Banjo Bill Cornett recording project, as well as Willie Dixon sheet music.

Various writings about Peru, including Cohen's 1957 MFA thesis and writings on Q'eros music. Materials related to the development and publication of
Hidden Threads of Peru
, including correspondence, sketches, maps, proofs, and drafts. Articles for
Sing Out!
and Folkways, including drafts, liner notes, notes, and interview transcripts. Includes the article, "Folk Art vs. Pop Art," written for
Sing Out!
, and then proposed as a book. Includes correspondence, with letters to Bob Dylan and Robert Frank, drafts, notes, and ephemera. Materials reflecting Cohen's written and photographic work, as presented in magazine, programs, and exhibits. Includes a transcription of an interview with Cohen, a book illustrated by Cohen, as well as posters, drafts, and correspondence. Includes Penny Cohen's fieldwork diary from Peru, as well as a logbook of Peru recordings.

scopecontent.p: Materials include Cohen's field recordings, encompassing music, interviews, audivisual materials from Cohen's film and musical projects, and a large collection of commercial Huayno 78rpm recordings. Titles of recordings are based on writing on containers of wire, tape, and other recording carriers. Digitized content available for select items. AFC 2011/059: SR108 through AFC 2011/059: SR111 are missing.

scopecontent.p: John Cohen's collection of approximately 450 45rpm commercial discs of Huayno music, traditional music of Andean people, which he assembled in Lima, Peru in 1988-1989 while working on a film about Huayno music. Most songs are sung in Spanish or in Quechua. Arranged by record label and catalog number. Performer names are documented as well. In his notes about the Huayno collection, Cohen writes, "there is a good representation of regional festival music, such as Santiagos (from Huancayo), Carnivals, and Tijeras (from Ayacucho)." Contact the Folklife Reading Room for further information about discs.
Selected discs from the Peruvian record label, Fabricantes Tecnicos. 25 of these discs have been digitized.

scopecontent.p:
Film and sound recordings from Cohen's film projects. Additionally there are unprocessed film parts and manuscripts associated with the following projects:
The Ballad and the Source
,
Carnival in Q'eros
,
Choqela: Only Interpretation
,
Dancing with the Incas
,
The End of an Old Song
,
Fifty Miles from Times Square
,
Gypsies Sing Long Ballads
,
High Lonesome Sound
,
Mountain Music of Peru
,
Musical Holdouts
,
Pericles in America
,
Peruvian Weaving: A Continuous Warp
,
The Post Industrial Fiddle
,
Q'eros: The Shape of Survival
, and
Sara and Maybelle
. Some of the film parts have preservation issues.

ca. 1990-1992

scopecontent.p: Photographic prints and digitized contact sheets relating to folk musicians, Peru, the Beat scene in New York, and Cohen's other projects and phases of life.

Photographic prints from various aspects of Cohen's life and career. Includes prints of the folk music scene in and around Greenwich Village, including musicians, concerts, jams, and folk festivals. Includes photographic prints related to Cohen's project,
Past Present Peru
. Materials document weaving and spinning traditions, as well as music, dancing, and other activities of communities in Peru. Descriptions are derived from Cohen's writing and labels.

scopecontent.p: The digitized contact sheets represent photographic negatives taken by Cohen from the 1950s until the 2000s. Areas of coverage include Peru, music festivals and performances, portraits of artists and musicians, film stills and production photos, as well as his early photographic work. Also included are family photographs. Notable figures appearing in the contact sheets include Roscoe Holcomb, Bob Dylan, Woody Guthrie, Earl Scruggs, Martin Luther King, Jr., Elizabeth Cotten, Eck Robertson, John Lomax and Bill Monroe.

John Cohen's life and career are divided into four major series: Yale/New Haven and Early Years (A series and F series); New York-Art and the Beat Scene (G and H series); Musicians (F, G, H, I series); and Peru (D and E series). The file names (digital identifiers) include these series designations in the letters assigned prior to the identifier number. Descriptions of contact sheets are from the collection inventory provided by John Cohen.

scopecontent.p: Large accrual complementing the 2011 John Cohen collection. Manuscripts and audiovisual materials encompass much of Cohen's career and personal interests. Digital content (optical media and floppy disks) is unprocessed and has been removed from associated boxes/folders. The extent notes identify the container from which the digital carriers were removed.

arrangement.p: The accrual/series is mostly arranged topically, by Cohen's area of interest, such as Peru and Southern U.S. music, but there is also a large subseries that documents the administrative side of Cohen's teaching, writing, photography, and film making career. Subseries are arranged alphabetically except for the "Original Artwork" subseries, which is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: Manuscripts and audiovisual materials concerning John Cohen's longstanding relationship with Peru and study of the Q'eros people in the Peruvian Andes. The series includes academic papers, research, and fellowship materials, as well as research materials for Smithsonian Folkways albums he produced, and extensive research on Huayno music. Includes manuscript materials related to his Peru film projects, as well as correspondence and administrative materials from his trips to Peru.

scopecontent.p: Working digital files related to the making of Cohen's 2014 documentary film, "Visions of Mary Frank." Digital content includes Final Cut Pro project files and a range of audiovisual file formats and still image formats that Cohen accumulated in the process of putting together the film. Files are in their original directory structure. Many of the Final Cut Pro files are very short clips, edits, render files or capture scratch files. Includes files from the film's cinematographer, Harvey Wang. Includes licensed materials subject to their own copyright.
